title: 107_hr1181
content: The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is a new section in the Internal Revenue Code that provides a credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals. The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" offers a tax credit for individuals who pay for qualified health insurance coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The credit is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for up to two individuals. The tax credit under the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for individuals covered by qualified health insurance paid by the taxpayer. Only the individual who is married but does not file a joint return and does not live apart from their spouse can be considered for the credit. The tax credit for individuals under the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for those not covered by qualified health insurance and not eligible for an employer-provided group health plan. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. The tax credit under the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for individuals without qualified health insurance or employer-provided group health plan. Modified adjusted gross income includes exclusions under specific sections. Applicable dollar amounts are $60,000 for coverage of more than one individual and $30,000 for other cases or married individuals filing separately. The tax credit under the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is limited to $1,500 per eligible coverage month for individuals without qualified health insurance or employer-provided group health plan. Modified adjusted gross income includes exclusions under specific sections. Applicable dollar amounts are $60,000 for coverage of more than one individual and $30,000 for other cases or married individuals filing separately. Qualified health insurance excludes coverage with less than 50% cost borne by the taxpayer and does not include certain government-provided programs like Medicare, Medicaid, and Indian Health Care Improvement Act. The tax credit for qualified health insurance under the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is subject to specific rules. Coverage under the program is considered as coverage under qualified health insurance for eligibility purposes. Special rules include coordination with other deductions, denial of credit to dependents, and inflation adjustment for taxable years after 2002. For taxable years after 2002, dollar amounts in subsections (b)(2)(A) and (c)(3) will be increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. Amounts will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $100. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. Part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section on costs of qualified health insurance. In general, individuals can deduct the amount paid for qualified health insurance coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Special rules apply, such as not double-counting the deduction with other medical expenses. The deduction does not apply to self-employment tax purposes. Conforming amendments include adding a new item for the deduction in the Internal Revenue Code. The table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended by adding a new item in accordance with section 222. The amendments made by this section regarding the costs of qualified health insurance and cross reference shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001.
